case_name: Nikhil Merchant v. Central Bureau of Investigation

facts.text: Leave granted in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: ALTAMAS KABIR,J. Leave granted. The question whether a First Information Report

facts.text: FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January 1997 lodged at P.S. Vivek Vihar East Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January, 1997 P.S. Vivek Vihar  East Delhi . J.  ALTAMAS KABIR  New Delhi DatedOctober 16, 2008

facts.text: Sanjay Pal resides at House No. A-25, Jhilmil Colony, Vivek Vihar, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Statement of Sanjay Pal S o Mahendra singh Pal R o House No. A-25, Jhilmil Colony, Vivek Vihar, Delhi, stated that I reside at the above mentioned address with my family.

facts.text: Sanjay Pal financed Maruti Van DL-1CB-4065 from Manoj Kumar Sharma of Vijay Lakshmi Finance Investment Company two years before FIR for Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: I got financed a Maruti Van bearing No. DL- 1CB-4065 from Shri Manoj Kumar Sharma - Vijay Lakshmi Finance Investment Company before two years back for a companysideration amount of Rs. 30,000/-

facts.text: Sanjay Pal paid Rs. 3954 as first installment.

anchor.surface_text: and I paid Rs. 3954/- as first installment. After that Shri Man Mohan Sharma R o D-131, Jhilmil Colony, came and told me that your finance is fabricated one,

facts.text: Man Mohan Sharma of D-131, Jhilmil Colony claimed finance was fabricated and transferred to Real Auto Deals run by his brother-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: After that Shri Man Mohan Sharma R o D-131, Jhilmil Colony, came and told me that your finance is fabricated one, that is why your vehicle has number been financed by me from Real Auto Deals which is run by my brother-in-law.

facts.text: Man Mohan Sharma received installments in cash every month without proper receipts or letterhead of Real Auto Deals.

anchor.surface_text: Man Mohan Sharma used to receive the installments in cash every month from me. The receipts issued to me put up with neither rubber stamp number used the letter head of Real Auto Deals.

facts.text: Cheques from Sanjay Pal were encashed by Man Mohan Sharma in different names instead of Real Auto Deals account.

anchor.surface_text: The cheques received from me, encashed him in different-different names instead depositing in the account of Real Auto Deals.

facts.text: On 27.12.1995 at about 10 O'clock, Man Mohan Sharma with unknown person took Maruti Van without consent using police stamped paper.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on 27.12.1995 at about 10 Oclock he came to me in Jhilmil along with an unknown person, I can recognize him if he companyes to me, took my said Maruti Van with his help without my companysent by showing me a paper duly stamped by the police.

facts.text: Vijay Lakshmi Finance, Real Auto Deals and Man Mohan Sharma sold the vehicle with forged signatures.

anchor.surface_text: Vijay Lakshmi Finance, Real Auto Deals and Man Mohan Sharma, have sold my vehicle to some other place by making my forged signatures and by playing fraud with me, in companynivance of each other.

facts.text: Charges framed against appellant Manoj Sharma and Man Mohan Sharma based on FIR.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the above FIR charges were framed against the appellant and companyaccused Man Mohan Sharma.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court to quash FIR on ground of compromise.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court for quashing the FIR on the ground that the matter had been companypromised between the companyplainant and the accused.

facts.text: Complainant filed affidavit withdrawing allegations due to settlement.

anchor.surface_text: In that writ petition an affidavit was filed by the companyplainant stating that in view of the settlement between the parties he is withdrawing the allegations against both the writ petitioners and he is also withdrawing the FIR.

facts.text: Settlement terms: Rs. 45,000 to Manoj Sharma and Rs. 45,000 to Man Mohan Sharma.

anchor.surface_text: As per the amicable settlement a sum of Rs. 45,000/- would be paid to the appellant Manoj Sharma and a further sum of Rs. 45,000/- would be paid to the companyaccused Man Mohan Sharma.

facts.text: Delhi High Court rejected writ petition on 17.8.2007.

anchor.surface_text: However, the Delhi High Court by the impugned judgment dated 17.8.2007 rejected the writ petition and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Special Leave Petition (Criminal) No. 5265 of 2007 filed, arose as Criminal Appeal No. of 2008.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.OF 2008 Special Leave Petition Criminal No. 5265 of 2007 Manoj Sharma Appellant -versus State Others Respondents

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal and quashes criminal proceedings in FIR No.50/1997 before Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court and quash the criminal proceedings pending before the learned Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997

facts.text: Dispute between complainant and accused is of private nature and settled.

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report, which had been lodged by the companyplainant indicates a dispute between the companyplainant and the accused which is of a private nature.

facts.text: High Court refused to quash under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the nature of the offences set out in the companyplaint, the High Court did number companysider it an appropriate case for exercising its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the same.

facts.text: Judgment dated October 16, 2008 by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: A First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 when accused and complainant have compromised and settled the matter.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed either under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or under Article 226 of the Constitution, when the accused and the complainant have compromised

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsed B.S. Joshi precedent; powers under S.482/226 allow quashing to prevent abuse of process despite non-compoundability.

holdings.text: Power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 to quash proceedings is not limited or circumscribed by Section 320 CrPC even for non-compoundable offences.

anchor.surface_text: Section 320 Cr.P.C. cannot be read in isolation. It has to be read along with the other provisions in the Cr.P.C. ... The said power is in no way limited by the provisions of Section 320 CrPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; S.482 non-obstante clause overrides; follows B.S. Joshi.

holdings.text: High Court's refusal to quash FIR under Article 226 due to nature of offences was incorrect; should have taken pragmatic view given private settlement.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the nature of the offences set out in the complaint, the High Court did not consider it an appropriate case ... The First Information Report, which had been lodged by the complainant indicates a dispute between the complainant and the accused which is of a private nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute private; complainant not pursuing; continuing futile.

holdings.text: Criminal proceedings in FIR No.50/1997 quashed as parties settled amicably in private dispute.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court and quash the criminal proceedings pending before the learned Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show settlement; private nature; exercise of discretion under S.482/226.

holdings.text: Proceedings under non-compoundable offences like 420/468/471/34/120B can be quashed on compromise in private disputes.

anchor.surface_text: offences under Section 468, 471, 34 and 120-B IPC which are mentioned in the FIR in question cannot even be compounded ... dispute between the complainant and the accused which is of a private nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not limited by S.320(9); pragmatic approach for civil-like disputes.

holdings.text: Proceedings under serious offences like Section 302 IPC, 307, 395, 304B cannot be quashed on basis of compromise.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that a case under Section 302 IPC or other serious offences like those under Sections 395, 307 or 304B cannot be compounded and hence proceedings in those provisions cannot be quashed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction based on gravity; public interest outweighs private settlement.

holdings.text: Section 482 CrPC has non-obstante effect allowing rare violations of other CrPC provisions to secure ends of justice.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary ... or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of non-obstante clause; not Euclid's formula from precedents.
